chapter.htmlHeader: What causes it?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• The causes of palpitations include [Raviele, 2011; Gale, 2016; BMJ Best Practice, 2018]:
    • Cardiac arrhythmias:
      • Supraventricular/ventricular extrasystoles or tachycardias — the latter can be life-threatening.
      • Atrial fibrillation and/or flutter — for further information, see the CKS topic on Atrial fibrillation.
      • Anomalies in functioning of pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs).
    • Structural heart disease:
      • Mitral valve prolapse.
      • Severe mitral or aortic regurgitation.
      • Mechanical prosthetic valves.
      • Congenital heart disease with significant shunt.
      • Cardiomegaly or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy — the latter can be life-threatening.
      • Heart failure — for further information, see the CKS topic on Heart failure - chronic.
    • Psychosomatic disorders:
      • Anxiety and panic attacks — for further information, see the CKS topic on Generalized anxiety disorder.
      • Depression — for further information, see the CKS topic on Depression.
      • Somatization disorders.
    • Systemic causes:
      • Hyperthyroidism — for further information, see the CKS topic on Hyperthyroidism.
      • Hypoglycaemia.
      • Menopause — for further information, see the CKS topic on Menopause.
      • Pregnancy — for further information, see the CKS topic on Antenatal care - uncomplicated pregnancy.
      • Fever.
      • Anaemia — for further information, see the CKS topics on Anaemia - B12 and folate deficiency and Anaemia - iron deficiency.
      • Hypovolaemia.
      • Orthostatic hypotension.
      • Phaeochromocytoma.
    • Drugs:
      • Sympathomimetic agents in inhaled beta-2 agonists (such as salbutamol), antimuscarinics (such as ipratropium bromide), and vasodilators (such as hydralazine).
      • Recent withdrawal of beta-blockers.
      • Drugs that prolong the QT interval, including non-sedating antihistamines (such as terfenadine), macrolide antibiotics (such as clarithromycin and erythromycin), antipsychotic drugs (such as risperidone), some antidepressant drugs (such as citalopram and escitalopram, tricyclics, and monoamine-oxidase inhibitors), and antifungals (such as itraconazole) [Thavendiranathan, 2009].
      • Alcohol, caffeine, nicotine, cocaine, heroin, amphetamines, ecstasy, and cannabis.
